Descr: NHS-accredited health apps found to be sending unencrypted personal information.
Adblock Plus, an ad-blocking app, removed from the Google Play store
Disconnect Mobile, an ad-blocking app, removed from the Google Play store
former classmate buys Amy Boyer's SSN and employer information online to stalk her, eventually kills her. Plans documented on a public web site
50M Living Social records compromised
50M Evernote accounts compromised, email addresses, usernames taken
80M Anthem patient records exposed
Drone spotted near a school raises privacy and safety concerns.
AVG changes privacy policy to allow more data sharing, raising privacy concerns.
Hackers accessed PII of 102M Playstation users.
Security breach leasks credit card numbers, as well as PII (including email addresses) of 70M Target customers.
Breach of Epsilon data exposes names and email addresses of customers of 108 retail stores, plus Citigroup  and the College Board.
User misunderstanding of Facebook wall functionality leads him to unintentional share a comment with a former classmate. Happy ending, he eventually marries the classmate.
Police used text messages on victim's phone to charge a contact with homicide. The contact claimed this was a violation of his privacy but appeals court found there was no expectation of privacy.
Undocumented Texas women arrested during gynecology appointment; lawyer claims a HIPAA privacy violation.
Touchstone Medical Imaging patient data accessible online.
Nude Snapchat images put online by hackers.
Human error' leads to second privacy breach on Vermont Health Connect.
254,000 Australian online dating profiles hacked
AdultFriendFinder website hacked, PII accessed, attackers tried to extract a ransom.
Ashley Madison website hacked.
Data breach at Tampa General Hospital.
Laptop with patient data stolen from Northwestern Healthcare Employee.
Hackers steal information on 2.9 million Adobe customers
Four McLean Hospital backup data tapes go missing, thousands affected.
Phishing attack compromises Partners Healthcare 3,300 patients.
Hacker compromises a database causing a PII leak for Westnet customers.
HIV clinic accidentally disclosed 780 HIV patients' personal information (names, emails) when distributing a newsletter.
CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield hacking incident; intruders gained access to PII of 1.1M members.
900 patients notified about a Heartland breach in which an employee inappropriately accessed patient records over a 14 month period.
Flash drive with employee data missing from Eastern Health office.
WHSmith accidentally emailed customer personal details of those completing contact form to all customers in their mailing list
AppOps feature that gave users some control over app permissions is removed in Android update.
Spotify changed its privacy policy on 8/19/15 to allow for broad data collection. This was met with a lot of user concern and they changed the language in September.
Lebanon, New Hampshire library stops participating in the anonymous communication network, Tor, after concerns are raised by police.
US Office of Personnel Management hackers gain access to sensitive information of over 20M people. Leak included PII such as fingerprints of secret agents.
Sony Pictures hack releases lots of sensitive data including emails.

Google agreed to remove links regarding an old criminal conviction, but the removal inspired lots of news articles that Google does not want to remove. ICO then issued the first public enforcement notice based on the "right to be forgotten".
Privacy concerns about Mattel's new recording Barbie.
Pictures of under-age girls in Maine and elsewhere repeatedly posted on Facebook. Considered revenge porn.
Snapchat's claims of the ephemerality of snaps found to be misleading.
Google begins allowing advertisers to target users based on email address.  Restrictions are in place to deter individual profiling of users.
Presidential candidate web sites found to often be poor on privacy (e.g. no privacy policy or inappropriate policies).
English woman posts revenge porn pictures on Facebook; later convicted under April 2015 law.
Security breach causes leak of Snapchat photos, possibly through 3rd party apps used to access Snapchat.
Microsoft reviews user emails as part of an investigation into stealing of trade secrets.
Unexpected linking of text to a Google+ account accidentally outed a transgender women when sending a text.
Hacker accesses records of 15M T-Mobile customers who applied for credit. Records were accessed through Experian, the vendor that processes T-Mobile's credit applications.
Kentucky man shoots down a drone hovering over his property. Drone owner says was attempting to take aerial shots of a friend's home.
Bug causes private chats to be visible to the friends of those chatting.

New ability to email Google+ contacts whose email address you do not already have, raises privacy concerns. There are controls over visibility of the actual email address and it is possible to opt out.
Court requires Yelp to report identities of anonymous reviewers of a carpet cleaner.
A Google advertiser targeted users based on health related browsing; a violation of Canadian privacy laws and Google policy.
Twitter changes "block" functionality to allow blocked users to see tweets and then rolls back the change based on negative user feedback.
Hulu sharing video watching histories, along with Facebook IDs, to market research firm comScore.
YouTube comments begin requiring a Google+ account , thus now potentially identifying anonymous YT users because of G+'s real names policy.
Some users of Google Talk and Google Hangout had chats misdelivered. Glitch was caused by a bug.
Explorer launch of Google Glass raises concerns about the privacy of those who encounter Glass wearers.
Edward Snowden goes public with details of the NSA's PRISM surveillance program.
Google Search autocomplete feature links a German entrepreneur with scientology and "swindle", reflecting that a high-volume of searches also make the link.
Google Play is discovered to share email addresses and often names of purchasers with app developers.
Exif data used to infer the location of wanted person, John McAfee.
Ubuntu version automatically searches Amazon in addition to local file system when user enters search term. Feature is on by default.
Google Search autocomplete links German prime minister's wife to prostitution, reflecting that a high volume of searches also make the link.
High school student in Saratoga, CA, was victim of sexual abuse by classmates, abuse was documented on social media. She later committed suicide.
A 16 year old girl was sexually assaulted by two students from her school and they publicized the assault on several social media services. Both were later convicted.
Quora new feature displaying who has viewed a post raises privacy concerns.
Orbitz uses the type of machine making the request to determine the priciness of goods to display.
Predictive assistant introduced, Google Now, perceived as creepy by some.
High school student victim of sexual abuse outs perpetrators on Twitter and Facebook
Those who opt-in to LinkedIn calendar feature enable sharing of detailed calendar data without clear consent.
Script made available for determining IP address of online Skype users.
Target uses purchases to infer pregnancy, promotes pregnancy related products to user and thus reveals pregnancy to family
Path app found to be uploading contacts without permission; an action possible at that time by many iOS apps
Google and various ad servers found to be circumventing Safari cookie setting to facilitate the +1 button (in Google's case)
AOL Instant messenger found to log chats perhaps indefinitely  and to prefetch URLs with no option to turn off prefetching feature.
Canadian teenager was raped and rapists distributed photographs of the incident. She later committed suicide.
Tracking cookie accidentally set by Facebook; even for logged out users.
Default privacy setting allows FitBit profiles to be surfaced by search engines, revealing sensitive activities of FitBit users.
Harvard students Facebook data gathered and shared for research purposes, with some anonymization steps but apparently without the permission of the students.
Google begins enforcing G+ real name policy and so deletes/blocks many accounts.
Etsy default settings make purchases, profiles, feedback posts and sometimes, names, publicly visible, surprising users.
FTC finds that the Chitika ad network is only respecting opt outs for 10 days; not the promised 10 years.
Google Doodle contest asks for last 4 digits of SSNs for child participants; surprising others who see it as unnecessary.
Facebook begins using face recognition to automatically suggest name tags for photos; users can opt out on a photo-by-photo basis. Feature raises privacy concerns.
Some Germans dislike having photos of their homes made publicly available in Streetview. Around 3% of German households request their homes be blurred
Foursquare sharing check-ins regardless of user privacy settings. Foursquare subsequently fixed the bug.
Referrer sent to advertisers from several social networking sites (MySpace, LiveJournal, Hi5, Xanga and Digg) includes the profile ID of the profile on which the ad appeared.
In some cases, the Facebook user ID could be inferred from the referrer sent to advertisers.
Google Streetview cars collected wifi payloads without the consent of the wifi network users. Came to light in 2010 but collection occurred from 2008-2010.
American University accused rapist outed on Facebook
Google Buzz exposed contacts of users who didn't change a default privacy setting. The setting wasn't noticed by most users.
A newspaper publishes sexual images of Max Mosley online and in print. He later wins a settlement.
E-readers found to be collecting detailed data about reading patterns.
Kid-directed websites found to set more cookies than many non-kid sites.
Data aggregator Klout launches. As a data aggregator, Klout makes it easier to find personal information about people through search.
Fed by on-site cameras, new app SceneTap summarizes demographic of bar patrons.
"Girls Around Me" app launches. Makes available on a map images of women near the viewer's location who have checked in using FourSquare and Facebook.
EZ-Passes are discovered to be read at various non-toll-booth sites in order to facilitate traffic tracking.
Researchers discover surprising permissions requested by mobile apps; users are surprised by the permissions.
Advertising code used by Angry Birds and other apps facilitates tracking by the government, one finding from the Snowden leaks.
Growth of mugshot sites, that use public records to surface old criminal records. Some require payment for removal.
Awareness of, and number or, revenge porn sites, grows.
LinkedIn defaults, confusing privacy wording in settings and unexplained contact suggestions cause user privacy concerns.
Awareness grows over volume of data collected by cars; bill introduced to afford users more concern over those data.
Growth of face recognition apps for Google Glass raises privacy concerns
ClassDojo launched in 2011. Privacy concerns around the data gathered about students and the usage of those data emerged in 2014.
Research project finds that 67% of kis apps collect personal information from kids.
New law requires companies to store data about Russian citizens in servers on Russian soil, raising privacy and freedom of speech concerns.
Amazon shows off prototype delivery drones on national television and raises privacy concerns amongst lawmakers
It's discovered that Microsoft scans Skype messages. This is allowed for by Skype's privacy policy but may surprise users.
Memorial Hermann Health System Notifies Patients of Privacy Incident. Clinical employee accessed patient's electronic medical record for 7 years outside normal job duties.
Cloud storage debacle marks hospital's third privacy incident in a year
Vitalite Health doctor accessed female patient files w/o authorization.

Some Uber users were surprised to find their "share my ETA" information to be findable using Google Search even though the users had shared the information publicly. Guidance from Uber was confusing. In September Uber started generating "share my ETA" links that expire in 2 days.
New tool makes users aware of default geolocation sharing by Facebook Messenger.
Facebook begins using views of pages containing the Like button to target advertising.
Facebook releases "Signal" a product that aggregates Facebook and Twitter public posts and makes them searchable by topic; some privacy concerns are raised.
Playdom amasssed and divulged PII of children who visited their websites, found later to be a violation of COPPA.

News of the World reporters found to be hacking voice mail accounts of celebrities and politicians over an extended period of time (voicemail known to be hacked in 2006, emails and more in 2009). Newspaper was closed as a result.
Apple mobile devices found to be storing locations over previous 12 month period, unbeknownst to users.
Comcast exposed PII of customers who had paid to keep the information private. A system upgrade failed to note the customers who had paid to keep the information private.
Leak of Neiman Marcus shopper PII due to malware.
130M credit and debit cards stored by Heartland Payment Systems exposed to cybercriminals due to malware.
56M payment cards compromised by malware infected PoS machines at Home Depot.
46M records compromised at TJMaxx, HomeGoods, Marshalls.
Bloomberg News reporters had extracted subscribers private information
Call-center workers for AT&T Inc. leaked confidential information on about 280,000 subscribers so that resellers could unlock used phones, federal regulators said Wednesday.

Healthfirst, is notifying approximately 5300 affected members and past members that their personal information may have been compromised in the course of a criminal fraud scheme perpetrated against Healthfirst
Southern Phone Company breaches customer privacy by publishing personal information of users who had opted out, Australian Communication and Media Authority (ACMA)  finds.
Some Android phones found to be broadcasting location history to anyone within wifi range; Google issued a patch fixing the problem.
Verizon found to be injecting perma-cookies to track users.
Meritus Medical Center notifies patients of improper access to data
Hundreds of iOS apps found to be collecting PII using private APIs. This is against Apple rules and the apps were later removed from the app store.

Increasing number of fraudsters posing as call center agents and collecting sensitive financial data from unsuspecting customers on the pre-text of giving financial advise. The data is then sold off to other 'gangs' who dupe people.
Billions of password from NetEase mail box is leaked

Global information services group Experian was attacked by hackers and one of it's server containing T-Mobile customer data was compromised . 
The data includes personal information for a combination of about 15 million customers and applicants in the U.S. who at one point may have applied for T-Mobile service.
Calls to understand insurance coverage appear to drive up insurance premiums, even when a claim is not filed.
US high school teacher forced to resign or be suspended when a picture of her with alcohol in 2009 is found by a parent.
Internet Explorer changes default setting for Do Not Track; DNT is now off by default.
Toysmart accused by FTC of selling the personal information of children who visit its sites.
Eli Lilli accidentally discloses email addresses of visitors to its Prozac site.
Users who visit the sites 2012 presidential candidates get tracked across the web.

Dorm mates of Tyler Clementi secretly video recording his romantic encounter with another man and shared it with classmates. Clementi later committed suicide and his dorm mates were charged with invasion of privacy.
Millions of user's email account, password, ip address is leaked at 1024 website (it's a website for adult video)

Photos of naked adolescents (middle and high school) found to be circulating in a small Colorado town, commonly stored on student phone using photo vault apps. Members of the football team are said to be heavily involved.
The personal account information of tens of millions of  China Telecom users is found to be vulnerable and potentially leaked.
Call centers analyzing voice data for emotional state of caller.
FBI improperly gained access to calling records of citizens. In some cases, reporters were targeted as part of leak investigations.
4 CIA officers were embedded in the NYC police department after 9/11; 1 working on surveillance. Concerns raised about lack of separation between agencies.
Topless sunbathing photos of Kate Middleton are published; royal family pursues legal action.
Blood test of mother of dead newborn used to convict her of chemical endangerment; evidence of methamphetamine was found in her blood.
Police departments are building DNA databases of potential suspects; some DNA data is collected without the owners knowledge.
FTC finds that 20% of 400 child-directed apps provide appropriate disclosure of data collection practices.
Callisto service allows victims of sexual assault to anonymously report the incident including submitting identitfying information about their attackers.
Audit by the state of North Carolina of consumer purchases made online raises privacy concerns.
Blippy, a social media service that facilitates sharing of purchases with friends, allowed the credit card numbers of some users to be indexed by Google.
European plans for a terrorist tracking system raise privacy concerns.
Windows 10 update was pulled because it forgot certain user privacy settings and re-set them to the defaults. The settings had to do with app behavior, e.g. app use of a unique advertiser ID.

Netflix released data  of user movie ratings with PII removed as part of a contest to improve its recommender algorithm. It was found that some users could be identified using the data set and other publicly available data.

Philadelphia school district remotely activated cameras on school-issued laptops often to locate them, raising privacy concerns. Students were not made aware that the cameras could be remotely activated and in some cases photos were taken of students who had possession of their laptops. Lawsuits against the school were eventually settled (http://articles.philly.com/2010-10-12/news/24981536_1_laptop-students-district-several-million-dollars).
Same-sex marriage opponents protest requests to turn over the names of petition-signers under the First Amendment.
France begins use of full body scanners at Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports; privacy advocates claim scanners are overly intrusive.
Bug gives Facebook users access to the chats of their friends and other private information.
Facebook changes privacy policy to require users to opt out of making certain information public, raising privacy concerns.
Google, Microsoft and Yahoo believed to be retaining user data longer than allowed under European Union laws.
US pressures Pakistan to provide more detailed information on those traveling to the US, raising privacy concerns.
Security breach at AT&T allowed the email addresses of >100K iPad users to be accessed.
Emails of faculty and staff at Harvard were searched as part of a student cheating investigation, raising a privacy outcry amongst the email account holders.
Germany Asks Apple About iPhoneâ€™s Data-Gathering
Teacher in training was denied her degree after she posted a picture of herself drinking on MySpace
A man was charged with 10 counts of murder based on genetic data collected from his son for another purpose.
Request from Obama administration to allow the FBI warrant-less access to the communication context around emails raises privacy concerns.
United Arab Emirates announces it will suspend Blackberry mobile services because it is unable to monitor communications using the services.
Obama administration medical privacy rules denounced as weak on privacy.
Consumers voice privacy concerns about online retargeting.
Consumers voice concerns about flash cookies; some launch lawsuits.
A Duke student circulated a powerpoint presentation on her sexual partners while a student, including their names and images, which eventually was published on the web.
Privacy concerns are raised about HTML 5 and evercookies.
Several Facebook apps (e.g. Farmville) found to be sharing PII with advertisers.
Instances of home surveillance footage showing misdeeds of neighbors are appearing on YouTube.
A US government employee accidentally sent a file containing the names and SSNs of all employees of the General Services Administration to a private email address.
Concerns are raised about the profiling and targeting of users of online health sites.
Military bases are using SSNs as identifiers in a variety of common settings like gym membership IDs, thus putting the military at heightened risk of identity theft.
The US Supreme Court upholds the practice of intrusive background checks of employees of government contractors. The practice was put in place after 9/11.
iPhones found to be storing user location data for a year.

A British legal ruling bars media outlets from publishing news about a celebrity affair that identifies one of the parties involved, but Twitter users identify the person and discuss the affair freely.
FBI agents are given more freedom to surveil and mine databases to scrutinize people of interest.
A database about needy NYC residents that aggregates across multiple government services raises privacy concerns.
A start-up that makes it easier for employers to review the social media presence of applicants raises privacy concerns although cleared by the FTC.
New business selling artwork and notebooks containing police mug shots from the 1950s raises privacy concerns.
Names and diagnosis codes for 20K Stanford Hospital patients were published on a commercial website for a year.

The existence of a list of well-connected applicants who were given an edge in admissions to University of Illinois is leaked and the university fights a request to release the names of the parents of the applicants.
Voter registration information exposed for 191M Americans due to a incorrectly configured database.
Judge orders Twitter to give information about 3 account holders who are under investigation for links to WikiLeaks.
Growth of apps that use face recognition to determine demographics of bar goers, raise privacy concerns.
A photo Randi Zuckerberg shared on Facebook ends up posted on Twitter because a Facebook recipient thought it was public.
Clear Channel partners with AT&T and other companies to track location patterns and behavior through cell phones.
11.5M documents from a Panamanian law firm containing sensitive investment information for many people including prominent politicians
Facebook Launches News Feed and Mini-Feed features and raises privacy concerns because user posts and profile changes are promoted in unexpected ways.
Apple fights court order to unlock accused terrorist (one of the San Bernadino shooters) iPhone and provide the FBI access to the unlocked phone.
Google's decision to support free email with contextual ads raises privacy concerns

In 1990 and onward, the Havasupai Tribe allowed Arizona State University researchers to collect blood for what they understood to be diabetes research. They later found out it was used to investigate other issues like inbreeding. In 2010 they won a settlement from the university. A legal analysis of the settlement is here: http://www.suffolk.edu/documents/Law%20Journal%20of%20H%20and%20B/Drabiak-Syed-175-225.pdf
Twitter troll victims used IP address and social networking information and data aggregators to identify trolls
Following pressure by a judge lawyers from Google and Oracle agreed  not to do any Internet research on jurors in their upcoming copyright trial.
Concerned raised about Oculus' rights to data of users of the Oculus Rift.
An North Carolina woman posted a photo online of a woman in an intimate situation and was later charged under NC's new revenge porn law
Uniquely identifying information is found to be sent to Microsoft by Windows 10, which may be surprising to users although perhaps allowed by settings and privacy policies
UK MP circulated a photo of a public servant in a bar, the woman filed a complaint of inappropriate behavior against the MP, possibly before the photo was shared

Runkeeper app found to be tracking user location even when the app is not active. The location information is shared with advertisers. This app behavior is considered a breach of European data protection laws by Norway.
New app that aggregates public information about individuals and encourages trading/selling people in a game-like environment raises privacy concerns
Apple removed some iPhone apps from store because they were found to be collecting private information due to a malicious advertising toolkit
Facebook offers new user control over tracking, but is criticized by some as being too limited

The privacy policy for Samsung Smart TVs contained vague language about audio capture and raised privacy concerns. The privacy policy was later revised to be more clear about when audio is captured and which 3rd parties the captured data is shared with.

Philips introduces system connected LED lights with customer smart phones to help customers find products. System uses visual light communications (VLC) to encode information. Privacy concerns are raised related to monitoring and data collection.

Chicago police are maintaining lists of potential shooting victims and shooters. The list is derived from an algorithm using 10 behavioral variables; demographics are not used. It is reported that 70% of those shot in 2016 were on the list. Privacy concerns include the use of these data for tracking/profiling and the fact that there is not process for people to contest inclusion in the list(s).
Stanford researchers demonstrated the power of phone metadata (e.g. numbers called, call duration) for inferring sensitive information like medical conditions and gun ownership.

Six North Carolina teens were charged in 3 different Facebook cyberbullying incidents. One of the teens later found guilty under NC's cyberbullying law was convicted but had his conviction overturned when the NC Supreme Court ruled the law unconstitutional in June of 2016 (http://lawstreetmedia.com/blogs/law/north-carolina-cyberbullying/).
Newport Television broadcast a recorded phone conversation that was recorded without the knowledge of the interviewee. They were later fined $35,000 by the FCC.

Android 'Brightest Flashlight Free' app found to be collecting user location and device IDs and sharing them with advertisers without user consent. An FTC investigation was later settle by the app maker.

Yelp was found by the FTC to be in violation of COPPA because it collected the personal data of users known to be under the age of 13 without parental consent from the years 2009-2013. In addition, mobile app developer TinyCo, a maker of child-directed apps, was also in violation of COPPA for collecting personal information without parental consent.

An IRB-approved study at Harvard took photographs of students and faculty in classrooms without their knowledge to study classroom attendance. Professors learned of the study when informed of it's finding. The IRB did not consider it a human-subjects study and so did not require consent.

AddThis, a maker of `share' and `follow' buttons and other web tracking technology was found to be using 'canvas fingerprinting' to uniquely identify browsers and devices. Some sites stopped using AddThis buttons after this finding.

Starting in late 2012, Nomi Technologies sold technology to stores that allowed for the tracking of customers via their cell phones. Nomi's privacy policy stated an opt out would be available but the FTC found that this was not the case.
Breach of mSpy data raises awareness of "stalking apps" and motivates Senator Al Franken to request again that such apps be investigated.

Verizon failed to provide with the ability to opt out of having their personal information used in marketing campaigns. Verizon discovered the omission but did not report it to the FCC until approximately 4 months later. Verizon eventually had to pay a $7.4M settlement.

The Facebook Beacon system posted about the purchases Facebook users made on other sites in their News Feeds, surprising users. This resulted in lawsuits  and Beacon was shut down in 2009 (2 years after it launched).
MIT 'gaydar' project demonstrates the ability to predict sexual orientation based on in-network Facebook profile information.
In a blog post Uber discussed how it's data could be used to find the cities in which 'one night stands' are most common. The blog post raised concerns about Uber's use of data and was later deleted.

PaymentsMD, a medical billing service, linked the payment of bills to allowing  access to customer medical records in a way that wasn't noticed by many users. The FTC later ruled the practice deceptive. PaymentsMD wanted access to the medical records for a new service it was developing.

In 2014, Facebook's "Year in Review" feature launched. It algorithmically compiled a collage of photos believed to be important to their poster and suggested the sharing of the collage. The collages brought back unhappy memories for some users (e.g. the death of family members). The feature was revised in 2015 (http://time.com/4152148/facebook-year-review-photos-2015/).
Two telecom companies, YourTel and TerraCom, were found to be storing personal user data on servers openly accessible over the Internet. The sister companies were later fined $10M by the FCC.

A partnership between Lotus Development and Equifax planned to build a large database of user personal data (demographics, prior purchases, etc.) available for sale to marketers. There was a strong backlash from consumers, largely on privacy grounds. The lack of an opt out was cited. The project was eventually abandoned.

By purchasing voter registration records for a modest fee and joining the records with anonymized data released by the Massachusetts Group Insurance Commission, Latanya Sweeney was able to identify the medical records of Massachusetts Governor, William Weld. This was one of the first incidents demonstrating the challenges of anonymization -- seemingly innocuous pieces of information can be identifying when combined.

Jet Blue airline shared more than 1 million passenger records with a government contractor in support of a project to identify travel patterns indicative of terrorists. This was reportedly a violation of Jet Blue's privacy policy and raised strong privacy concerns when discovered by the public.

AOL released millions of user queries, without explicit identifiers, for research purposes. Reporters were quickly able to identify some individuals who made the queries as many queries suggested personal attributes of the users such as location and interests.

The site Jerk.com began by scraping Facebook content and branding some profiles jerks and some non-jerks. The site sold subscription that claimed to allow users to manage their reputations. The FTC charged that Jerk.com misled customers (both in terms of suggesting the content was user-generated and in terms of the reputation management services advertised),  and the summary judgment was upheld under appeal. The site closed in 2014.

Uber is reported to have a practice of showing a non-anonymous God view at parties and to job applicants. In this view, the names and locations of everyone waiting for and taking an Uber ride are visible.
Researcher, Latanya Sweeney demonstrates that patient-level health information sold by Washington state can be combined with news reports to identify individuals.
Healthcare.gov found to be sharing personal health information (without explicit identifiers) with 3rd party marketers.
Sprint placed marketing calls to individuals who had registered themselves in the do-not-call list. This resulted in a $74M FCC fine.

On January 21, 2014, people in the area of protests underway in Kiev received a text saying "Dear subscriber, you are registered as a participant in a mass disturbance". The Ukranian government denied having sent the text.
Chinese military hackers de-anonymize themselves when they use the same network infrastructure both to launch attacks and log into Facebook and Twitter accounts.

FBI was able to identify the sender of the sender of threatening emails as Paula Broadwell using IP addresses associated with the emails sent from anonymous Yahoo and GMail accounts. This identification was also key to surfacing the affair between Broadwell and David Petraeus, former director of the CIA.
Australian hacker known as "w0rmer" was located and arrested largely based on the GPS coordinates embedded in a photo he posted on Twitter.

Researchers demonstrated how people can be identified from their DNA. They used the complete genome of some participants as well as their ages and state of residence, and combined this with publicly available genealogy databases, to identify likely surnames for the male participants. They were able to identify 5 of the 10 participants.

Rapper Jay-Z releases app that allows those who download to get a free copy of his new album, but the app's permissions  (e.g. location info, other apps on phone) raise privacy concerns and it is later removed from the Play store.
Equifax sold lists of people who were late on mortgage payments to Direct Lending Source and other companies. This resulted in a $1.6M settlement with the FTC.
Teletrak sold credit reports to marketers in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. This resulted in a $1.8M settlement with the FTC.
A Google Site Reliability Engineer viewed the Google accounts of some teenage friends for personal reasons. The SRE was later terminated.

The House voted to extend various expansions of the Patriot Act. The extensions allow the continued surveillance by the FBI of suspected terrorists despite changing numbers and cell phone providers among other things.

The state of New Jersey almost auctioned off computers containing sensitive information on thousands of people. The information included tax returns, social security numbers and files on abused children.

Pokemon Go mobile app game found to be gaining access to a player's entire Google account when Google is used to sign-in. Nintendo/Niantic responded that this was an error and it was fixed -- reportedly, the app only accessed user ID and email address. Original blog post by Adam Reeve: http://adamreeve.tumblr.com/post/147120922009/pokemon-go-is-a-huge-security-risk
Ghostnet, an electronic spying operation based in China, is found to have retrieved private documents from hundreds of government systems and private citizens, including the Dalai Lama.

The NSA is found to be covertly monitoring the emails of some prominent Muslim-Americans, potentially with warrants from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act court. Those monitored include a political candidate and several civil rights activists, academics, and lawyers.
The CIA improperly accessed the congressional computing system seeking documents stored by staffers.
Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) agents used a photos extracted from the phone of a woman who was arrested in July 2010, to create a fake Facebook profile and impersonate her.
WhatsApp changes its Terms of Service to allow for sharing of user phone numbers with Facebook regarding user devices and OSs. The changes raise privacy concerns
A student using Tor to send bomb threats to Harvard in an effort to delay final exams is identified, reportedly by analysis of metadata.

Democratic National Committee (DNC) computer systems are breached, reportedly by Russian hackers. Hackers gained access to many sensitive emails related to Hillary Clinton's campaign and led to the resignation of DNC chair  Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

Patients of a psychiatrist receive friend recommendations in Facebook; some of them realize that they must be all patients of the same doctor. It is suspected that the recommendations are due to them all having the psychiatrist's cell phone number and having given Facebook access to their phone contacts.

The UK Supreme court extends an interim privacy injunction preventing The Sun and other newspapers from publishing the name of a celebrity involved in a sexual encounter. The celebrity's identity and involvement were published elsewhere online.
In the UK the Data Retention and Investigatory Powers Act is passed, raising privacy concerns.

The UK government agency, GCHQ, covertly surveilled two international human rights groups. This was found to be illegal by the the judicial tribunal responsible for handling complaints against the intelligence services.
Edward Snowden reports to the Council of Europe that the US has spied on the staff of prominent human rights organizations.
Amazon's plans to reserve air space for delivery drones continues to raise privacy concerns.
4 million federal employees have their personal data compromised by a “zero day” attack.
Facebook announces it was hacked but there is no evidence that user personal data was accessed.
Guardian posts pictures of children's faces without parent permission. The pictures were later removed.
Ofcom report finds that the chairman of the football team Leads United inappropriately accessed computer files and broadcast private information through the club's in-house station Yorkshire Radio.
Australia’s human rights commission raises concerns Abbott government’s counter-terrorism agenda significantly expands surveillance powers and so undermines privacy.
Instances in which anonymous social sharing apps like Secret and Whisper are used to compromise the privacy of others are reported.
Facebook "Color Changer" App is found to be malicious, gains access to user personal information.

The Freedom of information website WhatDoTheyKnow.com reports it has recorded 154 accidental data leaks made by councils, government departments, police, the NHS and other public bodies in the UK since 2009.
Yahoo discovered a security breach enabled unauthorized access to over 500M accounts two years after the it occurred.
Yahoo reportedly complied with requests by the NSA and FBI to scan incoming emails for certain keywords/phrases.
